title: Super Retail Group steps up promotions as consumers stay cautious
text:
"In response to a cautious consumer, we have activated a higher level of promotional activity across the business, which has successfully generated top-line growth but adversely impacted margin."

The company gave no profit guidance but his comments suggest that profit growth is likely to fall short of sales growth, at least in the first half of 2020.

Same-store sales at Supercheap Auto rose 2.7 per cent in the first 16 weeks of 2020, compared with 3 per cent growth in the first six weeks, and 2.3 per cent in 2019.

At Rebel, same-store sales growth slowed to 3.1 per cent over the past 16 weeks, compared with 4.2 per cent growth in the first six weeks, but exceeded 3.3 per cent growth during 2019.

At boating, camping and fishing chain BCF same-store sales momentum improved to 6.5 per cent in the first 16 weeks compared with 5 per cent in the first six weeks of the year and 3.2 per cent growth in 2019.

Shift in timing

But at Macpac, sales went backwards as the outdoor leisure brand had strong 7.3 per cent sales growth last year, its first year of ownership by SRG, and changed the timing and duration of promotions. Same-store sales fell 2.1 per cent over the past 16 weeks, an improvement on the 3 per cent decline in the first six weeks of the year.

Across the group, total sales rose 4.2 per cent in the first 16 weeks, boosted by new stores, and like-for-like sales grew 3.2 per cent, compared with 2.9 per cent in 2019.

Advertisement

The figures provide little evidence that record low interest rates and tax cuts have significantly stimulated retail spending.

While retail sales are up marginally year on year, retailers say they are having to work harder and dig deeper than ever to convince customers to open their wallets, even though two rate cuts and two tax offset payments are estimated to have boosted disposable incomes by $16 billion.

Analysts and economists believe record low rates may be undermining consumer confidence in the economy rather than encouraging them to spend.

The Westpac-Melbourne Institute consumer sentiment index plunged 5.5 per cent in October to its lowest for four years. The weekly ANZ-Roy Morgan consumer confidence rating rose 0.6 per cent to 111.6 points this week after falling 1.2 per cent last week, but sentiment remains below the average of 114.4 points held since 2014 and the longer-term average of 113.1 points since 1990.

"Retail is tracking along OK but there hasn’t really been a step up [in spending]," one analyst said. "What Super Retail Group's trading update demonstrated is you have to do more promotions to drive traffic into stores."

Mr Heraghty, who took the helm in February, will update investors on the group's strategy next month.

He said there would be no major deviations and the group would continue to focus on delivering a seamless omni-channel retail experience for customers, integrating its supply chain to reduce costs, simplifying its conglomerate model to remove inefficiencies from duplication and legacy systems, personalising marketing, improving promotional effectiveness and leveraging its brands to create new profit pools.

"With the right strategy in place and an experienced management team focused on executing that strategy, we are well-positioned to grow our market share and create value for our shareholders," he said.
description: Shares fall 8.5 per cent as increased discounting helps boost sales but comes at a cost to margins.
